Award.AwardTitle: Self-Recognition in the Self-Assembly of Hydrophilic Macroionic Solutions
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program of the Chemistry Division, Tianbo Liu of the University of Akron will explore the properties of soluble macroions which represent a missing link between simple ions and large colloids. The research has three components: first, experiments will be performed to determine whether the self-recognition of macroions can be achieved under extreme conditions, such as tiny differences in charge, shape, extra ligands or center metal ions. In the second part, self-recognition amongst enantiomeric macroions and chiral counterions (or co-anions) will be studied. Finally, potential applications of the self-recognition feature in materials science, such as separating/purifying functional materials or chiral catalysis will be pursued. The proposed work could have impacts on other research fields, such as physical chemistry, supramolecular chemistry, biochemistry, materials sciences and nanotechnology. The project also involves training graduate and undergraduate students, as well as visiting local high schools to interact with the students and encourage them to participate in national science competitions and to pursue scientific careers in the future.

Self-recognition involves a molecule, or larger entity, that can selective "recognize" and associate with itself in solution or even a more complex mixture. This phenomenon is a universal and critical behavior in biological and chemical systems and leads to many important properties. This research seeks to further understand the self-recognition behavior of macroions (very large charged molecules) in solution, in order to enhance our fundamental knowledge of how the self-recognition occurs, what are the critical driving forces behind this phenomenon, and whether it can be achieved in chemical process that mimic biological ones. This research could provide scientists additional evidence to understand certain unsolved biological processes and might lead to potential applications such as catalytic materials or materials for separations and purification.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The PI’s group has been working on understanding the fascinating self-recognition behavior observed in macroionic solutions during their self-assembly, and exploring the fundamental reasons behind this phenomenon. Two types of macroions (large, charged ions), with almost identical size, shape, molecular architecture, are found to self-assemble into individual “blackberry”-type structures in their mixed dilute solutions. The discovery of biological level of self-recognition in simple inorganic porous microionic solutions is important, as it might show the possible reasons for various molecular self-recognition in biological systems.

     The PI 's group has further confirmed that the self-recognition behvaior can be achieved among enantiomers in their mixed solution, resulting in the formation of left-handed and right-handed blackberry-type structures, accordingly (Fig. 1). This leads to the interesting connection to the mysterious homo-chirality puzzle of lives, by showing that the chiral recognition can be maintained and amplified from macromolcules to supramolecular structures successfully. In addition, by adding a small amount of chiral co-ions, the PI observed that only one type of enantiomers would assemble while the other stayed as single ions in solution, leading to a chiral selection process (Fig. 2).

     The PI's group has identified that the self-recognition feature is closely related to the driving force of the blackberry structure formation, i.e., the counterion-mediated attraction. The group is able to address the following questions in the past three years:

(1) The blackberry structure formation is common for various macroions, such as inorganic polyoxometalates, inorganic-organic nanocages, cyclodextrins, small nanoparticles, functionalized C60 and dendrimers.

(2) The valence, type and hydrated size of counterions are critical for the self-assembly. The macroions can accurately dintinguish different monovalent counterions and choose the ones with highest priority.

(3) Initiall efforts has been started to use course grained simulation to understand the mechanism of the blackberry structure formation.

     Four students have obtained their Ph.D. degrees by doing research related to this grant, and have all successfully landed decent jobs: Fadi Haso (Saint-Gobain Inc.), Jing Zhou (Saint-Gobain Inc. Shanghai), Baofang Zhang (postdoc at Michigan State Univ.) and Yang Chu (Blue Solutions). One more is expected to defend in the summer of 2017 (Seyed Ali Eghtesadi).

     The research project supported by the grant has attracted eight undergraduate students through the 3+2 BS/MS program of our College of Polymer Science & Engineering. These students pay their full tuitions by themselves. This grant provides necessary resources for them to pursue their research work. Seven of them have graduated from the University of Akron with M.S. degrees in Polymer Science. Two of them are doing Ph.D. studies in the PI’s group now. The other five students have all been accepted by other institutions as Ph.D. students.

     One female African American college student did REU training in the PI's lab in the summer of 2016 for her future career preparation.

The PI has developed a new course for graduate students and senior undergraduate students at Akron, named “Physical Chemistry of Complex Solutions”, in Spring 2014. The new results from this grant (and the related previous ones) are incorporated into this course. It had very good enrollments in the first four years (~70 students in total) and has received very positive evaluations from the students.
